reference: B. In patients, 411 taxa across taxonomic levels from phylum to species increased with time, and 9 decreased with time according to linear mixed effect models with FDR<0.1
explanation: In patients, 411 taxa across taxonomic levels from phylum to species increased with time, and 9 decreased with time according to linear mixed effect models with FDR<0.1

question: How many metabolites were significantly different between TB_M0 and TB_M6? Options: A) 103 metabolites B) 212 metabolites C) 361 metabolites D) 428 metabolites
reference: C. By comparing each pair of groups with ANOVA contrast, 361 metabolites were significantly different between TB_M0 and TB_M6, 103 metabolites were significantly different between TB_M6 and TB_M15, and 428 metabolites were significantly different between TB_M0 and TB_M15
explanation: By comparing each pair of groups with ANOVA contrast, 361 metabolites were significantly different between TB_M0 and TB_M6, 103 metabolites were significantly different between TB_M6 and TB_M15, and 428 metabolites were significantly different between TB_M0 and TB_M15

question: Which of the following best describes the study's findings about beta-diversity? Options: A) Beta-diversity remained constant throughout treatment B) Beta-diversity of TB_M0 and TB_M6 were significantly higher than healthy controls and TB_M15, while TB_M15 was similar to healthy controls C) Beta-diversity increased progressively from TB_M0 to TB_M15 D) Beta-diversity was not significantly different between any groups
reference: B. The beta-diversity of TB_M0 and TB_M6 were significantly higher than that of healthy controls and TB_M15, while the beta-diversity of TB_M15 is similar to that of healthy controls, indicating recovery toward normal diversity levels
explanation: The beta-diversity of TB_M0 and TB_M6 were significantly higher than that of healthy controls and TB_M15, while the beta-diversity of TB_M15 is similar to that of healthy controls, indicating recovery toward normal diversity levels

question: What were the seven cytokines measured in this study using the Human Th1/Th2/Th17 kit? Options: A) IL-1, IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, IL-8, TNF, IFN-γ B) IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, IL-10, TNF, IFN-γ, IL-17A C) IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, IL-8, IL-10, TNF, IFN-γ D) IL-1, IL-4, IL-6, IL-10, IL-12, TNF, IFN-γ
reference: B. The BD CBA assessed Interleukin-2 (IL-2), IL-4, IL-6, IL-10, TNF, IFN-γ, and IL-17A levels in plasma samples using the Human Th1/Th2/Th17 kit
explanation: The BD CBA assessed Interleukin-2 (IL-2), IL-4, IL-6, IL-10, TNF, IFN-γ, and IL-17A levels in plasma samples using the Human Th1/Th2/Th17 kit

question: What was the average number of sequencing reads per sample obtained in this study? Options: A) 5,000,000 reads B) 10,000,000 reads C) 20,311,846 reads D) 31,329,790 reads
reference: C. The sequencing reads ranged from 496,978 to 31,329,790 across 122 samples, with an average of 20,311,846 reads per sample
explanation: The sequencing reads ranged from 496,978 to 31,329,790 across 122 samples, with an average of 20,311,846 reads per sample

question: According to the PERMANOVA test results, which time points showed significant differences from healthy controls in terms of gut microbiota composition? Options: A) Only TB_M0 was significantly different B) TB_M0 and TB_M2 were significantly different, while TB_M6 and TB_M15 were not C) All time points (TB_M0, TB_M2, TB_M6, TB_M15) were significantly different from healthy controls D) None of the time points were significantly different
reference: C. The gut microbiota of TB_M0 and TB_M2 were distinct from healthy controls. While TB_M6 and TB_M15 microbiota became more similar to healthy controls, they were still significantly different (PERMANOVA test: TB_M6 vs Healthy: R²=0.065, P=0.002; TB_M15 vs Healthy: R²=0.087, P=0.001)
explanation: The gut microbiota of TB_M0 and TB_M2 were distinct from healthy controls. While TB_M6 and TB_M15 microbiota became more similar to healthy controls, they were still significantly different (PERMANOVA test: TB_M6 vs Healthy: R²=0.065, P=0.002; TB_M15 vs Healthy: R²=0.087, P=0.001)

question: What is the significance of the study's findings regarding the persistence of gut microbiota alterations nine months after TB treatment completion? Options: A) It suggests complete recovery of the microbiome within 6 months B) It indicates that dysbiosis persists long after treatment and may contribute to increased vulnerability to recurrent TB C) It shows that the microbiome returns to pre-infection state immediately after treatment D) It demonstrates no relationship between microbiome changes and TB recurrence risk
reference: B. The study found that altered microbial community in the gut environment persisted for at least nine months after treatment completion. This gut microbiome dysbiosis induced by anti-tuberculosis treatment may contribute to the risk of recurrent TB, as it causes long-lasting damage that impacts the homeostatic role of the microbiome in inflammation and other metabolic functions essential for resistance against Mtb. This helps explain why treated TB patients are at least 8 times more likely to develop a new TB episode than the general population
explanation: The study found that altered microbial community in the gut environment persisted for at least nine months after treatment completion. This gut microbiome dysbiosis induced by anti-tuberculosis treatment may contribute to the risk of recurrent TB, as it causes long-lasting damage that impacts the homeostatic role of the microbiome in inflammation and other metabolic functions essential for resistance against Mtb. This helps explain why treated TB patients are at least 8 times more likely to develop a new TB episode than the general population

question: What were the alpha diversity indexes showing in PTB patients compared to healthy controls?
reference: The alpha diversity indexes of the PTB patients were significantly lower than the healthy controls (P<0.05). Specifically, Shannon (P<0.01), Simpson (P<0.05), Chao1 (P<0.001), and ACE (P<0.001) indexes all showed that the diversity of fecal microbiota in PTB patients was significantly lower than in healthy controls

question: Which bacterial genera showed increased abundance in PTB patients at the genus level?
reference: At the genus level, PTB patients had significantly higher relative abundance of Bacteroides (25.59% vs. 16.14%, P<0.05), Parabacteroides (2.88% vs. 0.90%, P<0.05), and Veillonella (4.24% vs. 0.84%, P<0.05) compared with healthy controls

question: How many participants were enrolled in the study and what were their demographics?
reference: A total of 69 pulmonary tuberculosis patients and 63 age- and sex-matched healthy controls were enrolled from the Affiliated Dongyang Hospital of Wenzhou Medical University from May 2021 to June 2022. Among them, 40 (63.49%) healthy controls and 44 (63.77%) PTB patients were men, with average ages of 49 and 51 years respectively

question: What sequencing method was used and which region of the bacterial genome was analyzed?
reference: 16S rRNA gene sequencing was used, specifically targeting the V4 hypervariable regions of the bacterial 16S rRNA gene. The samples were amplified using 515F and 806R primers and sequenced on the Illumina NovaSeq6000 platform

question: Which SCFA-producing bacteria were depleted in PTB patients?
reference: PTB patients showed a significant decrease in short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs)-producing genera including Faecalibacterium (5.31% vs. 14.80%, P<0.05), Bifidobacterium (1.67% vs. 5.02%, P<0.05), Agathobacter (0.86% vs. 3.32%, P<0.05), and CAG-352 (0.60% vs. 2.21%, P<0.05) compared to healthy controls

question: How does the gut microbiota imbalance affect biochemical indexes in PTB patients through lipopolysaccharide production?
reference: PTB patients showed an enrichment of Bacteroidota, Proteobacteria and Fusobacteriota, many of which produce lipopolysaccharide (LPS). The lipopolysaccharide biosynthesis pathway was significantly up-regulated in the PTB group. Chronic infection and persistent inflammatory reaction of tuberculosis may affect the integrity of the intestinal mucosal barrier, facilitating bacterial translocation and leading to increased circulating LPS. This LPS can induce insulin resistance and is related to hyperglycemia, which helps explain the high blood glucose level and low blood lipid level observed in PTB patients

question: Explain the relationship between SCFA-producing bacteria and clinical biochemical markers in the study
reference: SCFA-producing bacteria enriched in healthy controls (such as Lachnospiraceae_ND3007_group, Faecalibacterium, Roseburia, Dorea, and Butyricicoccus) were positively correlated with lipid levels (TC, TG, HDL, LDL), Albumin, and Hemoglobin. Particularly, Albumin was positively correlated with SCFA producers including Lachnospiraceae_NK4A136_group, Faecalibacterium, Dorea, Butyricicoccus, and Bifidobacterium (P<0.001). This indicates that the enrichment of probiotics in the intestine is closely related to the healthy physiological state of the host

question: How do SCFAs benefit human health according to the study's discussion?
reference: Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), especially acetate, propionate, and butyrate, are key mediators of beneficial effects from the gut microbiome. SCFAs can inhibit inflammation and regulate basic metabolism. They directly modulate host metabolic health related to appetite regulation, energy expenditure, glucose homeostasis, and immunomodulation. The study suggests that the reduction of SCFA-producing bacteria in PTB patients contributes to imbalance of intestinal flora structure and function, leading to pathological metabolism

question: What metabolic pathways were significantly altered in PTB patients according to PICRUSt2 analysis?
reference: PTB patients showed significant increases in 7 biosynthesis pathways related to ubiquinone, polyketide, siderophore, folate, lipopolysaccharide, N-glycan, and steroid hormone. Five metabolism pathways related to lipoic acid, ascorbate, taurine, fructose, and biotin were strikingly increased. The degradation capacities for amino acid and glycan were increased in patients. PTB patients had more pathways involved in toxin degradation and energy circulation, specifically reflected in the rise of peroxisome and TCA cycle pathways

question: What role does Lactobacillus enrichment play in PTB pathogenesis?
reference: Lactobacillus was significantly increased in PTB patients and was one of the significantly enriched taxa according to LEfSe analysis. Previous studies found that Lactobacillus was significantly increased in newly treated patients with PTB, and lactate, the product of Lactobacillus, was found to provide additional carbon matrix for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Additionally, Lactobacillus was negatively correlated with lipid levels (TG, Hb, LDL, TC) and Albumin in the study

question: Describe the folic acid biosynthesis pathway alteration and its relationship to Lactobacillus in PTB patients
reference: The biosynthesis of folic acid increased significantly in PTB patients according to PICRUSt2 analysis. This might be due to the enrichment of Lactobacillus in the PTB group, which is known as folic acid-producing bacteria. This represents one of the metabolic pathway changes that distinguishes PTB patients from healthy controls and demonstrates the functional impact of altered microbiota composition

question: Compare the phylum-level microbiota composition changes between PTB patients and healthy controls
reference: At the phylum level, PTB patients showed an enrichment of Bacteroidota (33.10% vs. 27.08%), Proteobacteria (12.99% vs. 9.83%), and Fusobacteriota (0.58% vs. 0.56%, P<0.05), while displaying a remarkable decrease of Firmicutes (48.07% vs. 55.89%, P<0.05) and Actinobacteriota (2.44% vs. 5.83%, P<0.01) compared with healthy controls. This shift represents a fundamental change in gut microbiota architecture

question: What diagnostic biomarker combination was identified for PTB and what was its performance?
reference: A random forest model was constructed using 30 genus markers. Six genera were identified as having the best combined diagnostic ability: Lactobacillus (AUC=0.758), Faecalibacterium (AUC=0.803), Roseburia (AUC=0.829), Dorea (AUC=0.851), Monnoglobus (AUC=0.867), and [Eubacterium]_ventriosum_group (AUC=0.88). The model including all six genera had a diagnostic ability of AUC=0.90, which is better than the overall 30 genera model (AUC=0.91), indicating this combination might be a set of new diagnostic biomarkers for PTB with improved accuracy and reduced complexity

question: How does the microbial interaction network differ between PTB patients and healthy controls, and what does this suggest?
reference: Based on the relative abundance of OTUs, PTB patients showed a more complex network of interactions than healthy controls, with more positive and negative correlations among the microbiota. This increased complexity in microbial interactions suggests that the PTB-associated dysbiosis involves not just changes in individual taxa abundances, but alterations in the dynamic interactions between community members, which may contribute to the destabilization of the gut ecosystem

question: Explain the proposed mechanism by which gut microbiota dysbiosis affects PTB pathology through the gut-lung axis and nutrient metabolism
reference: The study hypothesizes that changes in gut microbiota exert an impact on PTB clinical characteristics through the gut-lung axis by regulating the nutrient utilization pathway. PTB patients showed enrichment of pro-inflammatory bacteria and reduction of SCFA-producing probiotics, causing imbalance in intestinal flora structure and function. This dysbiosis led to pathological metabolism in the PTB group, with significantly increased metabolism/degradation pathways of amino acids and glycan indicating an increased basal metabolic rate consistent with low fever pathology of PTB. The upregulation of these pathways resulted from complicated microbial interaction networks demanding more nutrients. Additionally, increased LPS production from anaerobic bacteria facilitated by compromised intestinal barrier integrity further aggravated host inflammation, connecting microbiota changes to the clinical manifestations of malnutrition, altered lipid metabolism, and hyperglycemia in PTB patients

question: How many high-quality reads were generated in total from the 16S rRNA gene sequencing? Options: A) 7,296,048 B) 16,259,048 C) 12,259,048 D) 20,259,048
reference: B. In total, the study generated 16,259,048 high-quality reads, and these reads were clustered into 7,296 operational taxonomic units (OTUs) based on a similarity of 97%
explanation: In total, the study generated 16,259,048 high-quality reads, and these reads were clustered into 7,296 operational taxonomic units (OTUs) based on a similarity of 97%

question: What was the average albumin level in PTB patients compared to healthy controls? Options: A) 46.86 g/L in PTB, 32.62 g/L in HC B) 32.62 g/L in PTB, 46.86 g/L in HC C) 40.00 g/L in PTB, 45.00 g/L in HC D) 35.00 g/L in PTB, 42.00 g/L in HC
reference: B. Albumin (Alb) levels were significantly lower in PTB patients at 32.62 g/L (range 14.90-44.60) compared to healthy controls at 46.86 g/L (range 41.60-51.80), with P<0.001
explanation: Albumin (Alb) levels were significantly lower in PTB patients at 32.62 g/L (range 14.90-44.60) compared to healthy controls at 46.86 g/L (range 41.60-51.80), with P<0.001

question: Which database was used for taxonomic annotation of OTU representative sequences? Options: A) Greengenes B) RDP C) SILVA138 D) NCBI
reference: C. The representative sequences were annotated through QIIME2 (v2020.6) based on the SILVA138 database to generate the OTU list for taxonomic classification
explanation: The representative sequences were annotated through QIIME2 (v2020.6) based on the SILVA138 database to generate the OTU list for taxonomic classification

question: At the family level, which of the following showed increased abundance in PTB patients? Options: A) Bifidobacteriaceae and Ruminococcaceae B) Bacteroidaceae and Tannerellaceae C) Butyricicoccaceae and Ruminococcaceae D) Lachnospiraceae and Prevotellaceae
reference: B. At the family level, PTB patients showed significantly increased relative abundance of Bacteroidaceae (24.59% vs. 16.14%, P<0.05), Tannerellaceae (2.88% vs. 0.90%, P<0.05), and Oscillospiraceae (2.19% vs. 1.18%, P<0.05), while families like Bifidobacteriaceae, Butyricicoccaceae, and Ruminococcaceae decreased
explanation: At the family level, PTB patients showed significantly increased relative abundance of Bacteroidaceae (24.59% vs. 16.14%, P<0.05), Tannerellaceae (2.88% vs. 0.90%, P<0.05), and Oscillospiraceae (2.19% vs. 1.18%, P<0.05), while families like Bifidobacteriaceae, Butyricicoccaceae, and Ruminococcaceae decreased

question: How many unique OTUs were found exclusively in PTB patients versus healthy controls according to the Venn diagram? Options: A) 732 in PTB, 1141 in HC B) 1141 in PTB, 732 in HC C) 5423 in PTB, 732 in HC D) 732 in PTB, 5423 in HC
reference: A. The Venn diagram showed that 1,141 OTUs were unique in the healthy controls and 732 OTUs were unique in the PTB patients, with 5,423 OTUs shared between both groups
explanation: The Venn diagram showed that 1,141 OTUs were unique in the healthy controls and 732 OTUs were unique in the PTB patients, with 5,423 OTUs shared between both groups

question: According to LEfSe analysis, which genus was enriched in healthy controls with the highest significance? Options: A) Lactobacillus B) Faecalibacterium C) Bifidobacterium D) Multiple genera including Faecalibacterium, Bifidobacterium, and Roseburia
reference: D. LEfSe analysis demonstrated that multiple genera were enriched in healthy controls including Faecalibacterium, Bifidobacterium, Butyricicoccus, Roseburia, and Lachnospiraceae_NK4A136_group, while Lactobacillus, Blautia, Erysipelatoclostridium, and Fusobacterium were enriched in PTB patients
explanation: LEfSe analysis demonstrated that multiple genera were enriched in healthy controls including Faecalibacterium, Bifidobacterium, Butyricicoccus, Roseburia, and Lachnospiraceae_NK4A136_group, while Lactobacillus, Blautia, Erysipelatoclostridium, and Fusobacterium were enriched in PTB patients

question: What correlation pattern was observed between glucose levels and gut microbiota? Options: A) Positive correlation with SCFA producers B) Negative correlation with SCFA producers only C) No correlation with any bacteria D) Both positive and negative correlations with different bacteria
reference: B. Glucose (Glu) levels only had a negative correlation with SCFA-producing bacteria such as Incertae_Sedis, Faecalibacterium, [Eubacterium]_eligens_group, Collinsella, Ruminococcus, CAG-352, Bilophila, Akkermanisia, and Clostridia_UCG-014 (P<0.05), with no positive correlations reported
explanation: Glucose (Glu) levels only had a negative correlation with SCFA-producing bacteria such as Incertae_Sedis, Faecalibacterium, [Eubacterium]_eligens_group, Collinsella, Ruminococcus, CAG-352, Bilophila, Akkermanisia, and Clostridia_UCG-014 (P<0.05), with no positive correlations reported

question: Which biochemical parameter showed NO statistical difference between PTB patients and healthy controls? Options: A) Hemoglobin B) Total Cholesterol C) White Blood Cell count D) Albumin
reference: C. Among all the clinical biochemical indexes tested, there was no statistical difference in White Blood Cells (WBC) between the two groups, while all other parameters including Albumin, Creatinine, Hemoglobin, lipids, and glucose showed significant differences (P<0.05 or P<0.001)
explanation: Among all the clinical biochemical indexes tested, there was no statistical difference in White Blood Cells (WBC) between the two groups, while all other parameters including Albumin, Creatinine, Hemoglobin, lipids, and glucose showed significant differences (P<0.05 or P<0.001)

question: What is the proposed mechanism connecting Erysipelatoclostridium enrichment to PTB pathology? Options: A) It produces beneficial SCFAs that help fight infection B) It is associated with inflammation and lipid metabolism alterations C) It directly kills Mycobacterium tuberculosis D) It enhances immune response against tuberculosis
reference: B. Erysipelatoclostridium was one of the major genera associated with active tuberculosis and was found to be associated with inflammation as well as lipid metabolism. It was enriched in PTB patients and negatively correlated with beneficial biochemical indexes like TG, Hb, LDL, and TC
explanation: Erysipelatoclostridium was one of the major genera associated with active tuberculosis and was found to be associated with inflammation as well as lipid metabolism. It was enriched in PTB patients and negatively correlated with beneficial biochemical indexes like TG, Hb, LDL, and TC

question: Based on the study's findings, which intervention strategy is most supported for PTB management? Options: A) Increasing antibiotic diversity B) Supplementing with probiotics to restore SCFA-producing bacteria C) Eliminating all Lactobacillus species D) Reducing dietary fiber intake
reference: B. The study concludes that enrichment of pro-inflammatory bacteria and reduction of SCFA-producing probiotics in PTB patients caused imbalance in intestinal flora structure and function. The authors state it is meaningful to take probiotics to regulate the structure and function of the flora, as SCFAs can inhibit inflammation and regulate basic metabolism. The study suggests that replenishing probiotics seems feasible for PTB treatment due to their excellent ability in improving flora structure and increasing SCFA production
explanation: The study concludes that enrichment of pro-inflammatory bacteria and reduction of SCFA-producing probiotics in PTB patients caused imbalance in intestinal flora structure and function. The authors state it is meaningful to take probiotics to regulate the structure and function of the flora, as SCFAs can inhibit inflammation and regulate basic metabolism. The study suggests that replenishing probiotics seems feasible for PTB treatment due to their excellent ability in improving flora structure and increasing SCFA production

question: How many samples were used in the initial training dataset and testing dataset?
reference: The study first sequenced the metagenomes of 61 fecal samples from 31 healthy controls (C group) and 30 TB patients (P group) for the training dataset. Another 16 patients were sequenced and used as the patient group (Test-P) in the testing dataset. For validation, 30 healthy controls (Test-H group) were randomly selected from a type 2 diabetes cohort study

question: What taxonomic profiling tool was used and how many phyla, genera, and species were identified?
reference: MetaPhlAn2 was used for taxonomic profiling. Using this tool, the researchers identified 11 phyla, 156 genera, and 400 species across the three groups

question: Which two species were enriched in TB patients compared to healthy controls?
reference: Only two species were found enriched in TB patients: an unclassified Coprobacillus bacterium and Clostridium bolteae. Notably, C. bolteae is a frequently reported autism-associated bacterium that has also been found enriched in type 2 diabetes patients

question: What sequencing platform and insert size were used for library construction?
reference: DNA sequencing libraries with insert sizes of 350 bp were constructed following Illumina manufacturer's instructions. The libraries were then paired-end sequenced on the HiSeq 2500 Illumina sequencers, obtaining approximately 5 GB of clean data for each sample on average

question: How many SCFA-producing bacteria were enriched in healthy controls and what types were they?
reference: Nine out of the 23 control-enriched bacteria were widely reported SCFA-producing bacteria, including five butyrate producers (Roseburia inulinivorans, R. hominis, R. intestinalis, Eubacterium rectale, and Coprococcus comes), two lactate and acetate producers (Bifidobacterium adolescentis and B. longum), and two acetate and propionate producers (Ruminococcus obeum and Akkermansia muciniphila)

question: Explain the gut-lung axis hypothesis and its bidirectional mechanisms
reference: The gut-lung axis hypothesis suggests dynamic cross talk between the microbiota of the respiratory tract and the gut. The processes are bidirectional, occurring either via the translocation of local bacteria to the other site or through the release of immunomodulatory molecules (bacteria-derived components or metabolites, such as short-chain fatty acids [SCFAs]) into the bloodstream, thus affecting systemic immunity

question: What were the findings regarding metabolic pathway alterations in TB patients?
reference: In total, 110 metabolic pathways were found differentially enriched between the controls and patients (FDR<0.1), with 87 over-represented in healthy controls and only 23 enriched in patients, suggesting an overall decrease in metabolic potentials in TB patients. One hundred and six of these pathways belonged to three categories: Biosynthesis, Degradation/Utilization/Assimilation, and Generation of Precursor Metabolites and Energy. Notably, five pathways related to SCFA fermentation were strikingly decreased in TB patients

question: Describe the vitamin biosynthesis pathway differences between TB patients and healthy controls
reference: Six vitamin biosynthesis pathways related to folate, pantothenate, vitamin B6, thiamine, and flavin biosynthesis were highly represented in TB patients, while only the biotin and ascorbate biosynthetic pathways were more abundant in healthy controls. This represents an interesting reversal where patients showed higher capacity for certain vitamin biosynthesis pathways

question: How do SCFAs affect host inflammatory and immune responses according to the study?
reference: SCFAs exert remarkable effects on host inflammatory and immune responses. The decreased abundance of SCFA-producers has been observed in patients with inflammation-associated diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), colorectal cancer, and type 2 diabetes. The loss of SCFA producers and associated pathways in TB patients may indicate elevated systemic inflammation and impairment of the systemic immune response

question: What is the significance of Clostridium bolteae enrichment in TB patients in relation to other diseases?
reference: Clostridium bolteae is a frequently reported autism-associated bacterium that has also been found enriched in type 2 diabetes patients. Interestingly, both autism and T2D are closely connected with immune system abnormalities, and M. tuberculosis infections demonstrate strong interactions with the human immune system. A causal link between mycobacterial infection and autism has been proposed, while an increased risk for M. tuberculosis infection in T2D patients has been recognized for centuries. This suggests there may be a shared alteration in immune signals that induces the similarly observed enrichment of C. bolteae across these conditions

question: Explain the conflicting evidence regarding SCFAs and tuberculosis risk
reference: While the study found decreased SCFA-producing bacteria in TB patients suggesting potential benefits of SCFAs, there is conflicting evidence. Increased SCFAs in the lungs of HIV patients after antiretroviral therapy has been suggested to increase TB risk by suppressing IFN-γ and IL-17A production. This paradox indicates that the role of SCFAs and the causality between active TB and the decrease of SCFA-producing bacteria should be further defined

question: Compare the species number and alpha diversity between TB patients and healthy controls with statistical significance
reference: The number of species present in TB patients was significantly decreased compared to healthy controls (P = 1.95E-5; Wilcoxon rank-sum test). Consistently, the Shannon index indicating within-sample (α) diversity was much lower for the patient groups than for the controls (P = 2.84E-4; Wilcoxon rank-sum test). This demonstrates a dramatic reduction in both species richness and diversity in TB patients

question: What was the performance of the random forest classification model in both training and testing datasets?
reference: The random forest model using three species markers (Haemophilus parainfluenzae, Roseburia inulinivorans, and R. hominis) achieved an AUC of 84.6% with a 95% confidence interval of 0.651-0.956 in the training set (n=31 controls and 30 patients). When validated on an independent test set consisting of 16 patients and 30 healthy controls, the model performed well with an AUC of 0.767 and a 95% CI of 0.614-0.920

question: Describe the SNP analysis findings in Bacteroides vulgatus and their implications
reference: Among six species selected for SNP distribution analysis, B. vulgatus was the most prevalent, presenting in 70 samples. Forty-six SNPs in B. vulgatus were differentially distributed between the two groups. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that control samples could be largely clustered together and separated from patient samples, suggesting distinct mutation patterns between groups. Eight SNPs were located in seven carbohydrate metabolism genes including those encoding β-galactosidase, α-N-arabinofuranosidase, α-1,2-mannosidase, rhamnulokinase, Rhamnogalacturonides degradation protein, β-galactosidase, and D-lactate dehydrogenase. This suggests an altered carbohydrate preference and different carbohydrate metabolism patterns in the gut bacteria of TB patients

question: What are the limitations and future directions mentioned in the study regarding causality and diagnostic potential?
reference: The study found significant dysbiosis of gut microbiota in TB patients, but the causal relationship remains to be determined. While it's likely these changes were caused by M. tuberculosis infection based on similar results in murine models, the possibility that dysbiosis precedes and contributes to infection cannot be excluded. Additionally, as only TB patients and healthy controls were included, it's unclear if the gut bacteria and suggested model can discriminate TB patients from other non-TB patients. To be a potential diagnostic method, the accuracy and specificity should be validated in large-scale sampling studies. Finally, the findings were observed in active TB infection; the gut microbiota signature in latent TB infection still needs investigation

question: Which database was used for metabolic pathway annotation in the functional profiling analysis? Options: A) KEGG B) MetaCyc C) Reactome D) BioCyc
reference: B. Metabolic pathway analysis was performed using the program HUMAnN2, which uses the MetaCyc Metabolic Pathway Database for annotation. MetaCyc currently contains 2526 experimentally elucidated metabolic pathways involved in both primary and secondary metabolism
explanation: Metabolic pathway analysis was performed using the program HUMAnN2, which uses the MetaCyc Metabolic Pathway Database for annotation. MetaCyc currently contains 2526 experimentally elucidated metabolic pathways involved in both primary and secondary metabolism

question: What was the NCBI accession number for the metagenomic sequencing data? Options: A) SRP118759 B) SRP118957 C) SRA118759 D) SRX118759
reference: A. The metagenomic sequencing data have been deposited to NCBI Sequence Read Archive database under the accession number SRP118759
explanation: The metagenomic sequencing data have been deposited to NCBI Sequence Read Archive database under the accession number SRP118759

question: How many differentially enriched species were found between TB patients and healthy controls (FDR<0.1)? Options: A) 15 species B) 20 species C) 25 species D) 30 species
reference: C. The study found that 25 species were differentially enriched in the two groups. Among these species, 23 were enriched in healthy controls, while only 2 were more abundant in patients (Wilcoxon rank-sum test, FDR<0.1)
explanation: The study found that 25 species were differentially enriched in the two groups. Among these species, 23 were enriched in healthy controls, while only 2 were more abundant in patients (Wilcoxon rank-sum test, FDR<0.1)

question: What filtering criteria were used for metagenomic SNP calling regarding genome coverage and sequencing depth? Options: A) ≥30% coverage with >10× depth; SNP sites covered by ≥5 reads B) ≥40% coverage with >15× depth; SNP sites covered by ≥10 reads C) ≥50% coverage with >20× depth; SNP sites covered by ≥15 reads D) ≥60% coverage with >25× depth; SNP sites covered by ≥20 reads
reference: B. The filtering criteria for SNP calling were: ≥40% of the reference genome was covered with >15× average depth; SNP sites were covered by ≥10 reads in at least 20% of samples in each group
explanation: The filtering criteria for SNP calling were: ≥40% of the reference genome was covered with >15× average depth; SNP sites were covered by ≥10 reads in at least 20% of samples in each group

question: Which three species were selected as optimal markers in the random forest model? Options: A) Bacteroides vulgatus, Prevotella copri, and Clostridium bolteae B) Haemophilus parainfluenzae, Roseburia inulinivorans, and Roseburia hominis C) Bifidobacterium adolescentis, Eubacterium rectale, and Akkermansia muciniphila D) Coprococcus comes, Ruminococcus obeum, and Bifidobacterium longum
reference: B. Five repeats of 10-fold cross-validation led to the optimal selection of three species markers: Haemophilus parainfluenzae and two butyrate-producing bacteria, R. inulinivorans and R. hominis, for correct classification
explanation: Five repeats of 10-fold cross-validation led to the optimal selection of three species markers: Haemophilus parainfluenzae and two butyrate-producing bacteria, R. inulinivorans and R. hominis, for correct classification

question: How many metabolic pathways were enriched in healthy controls versus TB patients? Options: A) 87 in controls, 23 in patients B) 23 in controls, 87 in patients C) 106 in controls, 4 in patients D) 55 in controls, 55 in patients
reference: A. Among 110 differentially enriched metabolic pathways (FDR<0.1), 87 were over-represented in healthy controls while only 23 were enriched in patients, suggesting an overall decrease in metabolic potentials in TB patients
explanation: Among 110 differentially enriched metabolic pathways (FDR<0.1), 87 were over-represented in healthy controls while only 23 were enriched in patients, suggesting an overall decrease in metabolic potentials in TB patients

question: What was the P-value for NMDS analysis at axis 2 distinguishing controls from patients? Options: A) P=0.036 B) P=0.000024 C) P=1.94E-5 D) P=2.84E-4
reference: B. NMDS analysis based on genus relative abundance revealed striking differences between controls and patients especially at the NMDS 2 axis with P=0.000024, while NMDS 1 axis showed P=0.036
explanation: NMDS analysis based on genus relative abundance revealed striking differences between controls and patients especially at the NMDS 2 axis with P=0.000024, while NMDS 1 axis showed P=0.036

question: Which tool was used for metagenomic SNP calling and strain profiling? Options: A) SAMtools B) GATK C) MIDAS (Metagenomic Intra-species Diversity Analysis System) D) VarScan
reference: C. The identification of metagenomic SNPs was performed using MIDAS (Metagenomic Intra-species Diversity Analysis System). SNP calling was carried out when species had sufficient sequencing coverage and depth, with reads aligned to representative genomes to identify SNPs and estimate allele frequencies
explanation: The identification of metagenomic SNPs was performed using MIDAS (Metagenomic Intra-species Diversity Analysis System). SNP calling was carried out when species had sufficient sequencing coverage and depth, with reads aligned to representative genomes to identify SNPs and estimate allele frequencies

question: What is the proposed mechanism by which decreased SCFA-producing bacteria might affect TB pathogenesis? Options: A) Direct killing of M. tuberculosis B) Enhanced antibiotic resistance C) Elevated systemic inflammation and impairment of systemic immune response D) Increased vitamin production
reference: C. The loss of SCFA producers and associated pathways in TB patients may indicate elevated systemic inflammation and impairment of the systemic immune response. SCFAs exert remarkable effects on host inflammatory and immune responses, and their decrease has been observed in patients with inflammation-associated diseases such as IBD, colorectal cancer, and T2D
explanation: The loss of SCFA producers and associated pathways in TB patients may indicate elevated systemic inflammation and impairment of the systemic immune response. SCFAs exert remarkable effects on host inflammatory and immune responses, and their decrease has been observed in patients with inflammation-associated diseases such as IBD, colorectal cancer, and T2D

question: Based on the B. vulgatus SNP analysis, what was the primary functional category affected by differentially distributed SNPs? Options: A) Lipid metabolism B) Protein synthesis C) Carbohydrate metabolism D) Nucleotide biosynthesis
reference: C. Eight of the 46 differentially distributed SNPs in B. vulgatus were located in seven carbohydrate metabolism genes including those encoding β-galactosidase, α-N-arabinofuranosidase, α-1,2-mannosidase, rhamnulokinase, Rhamnogalacturonides degradation protein, β-galactosidase, and D-lactate dehydrogenase. This suggests an altered carbohydrate preference and different carbohydrate metabolism patterns in the gut bacteria of TB patients, making carbohydrate metabolism the primary affected category
explanation: Eight of the 46 differentially distributed SNPs in B. vulgatus were located in seven carbohydrate metabolism genes including those encoding β-galactosidase, α-N-arabinofuranosidase, α-1,2-mannosidase, rhamnulokinase, Rhamnogalacturonides degradation protein, β-galactosidase, and D-lactate dehydrogenase. This suggests an altered carbohydrate preference and different carbohydrate metabolism patterns in the gut bacteria of TB patients, making carbohydrate metabolism the primary affected category

question: How many stool metagenomes were analyzed in total across all cohorts in this study?
reference: The study analyzed 3,741 stool metagenomes from 18 cohorts across 11 countries, including 1,471 CRC samples, 702 adenoma samples, and 1,568 control samples

question: What was the average AUC achieved for CRC prediction using the LODO approach?
reference: The LODO (leave-one-dataset-out) approach achieved an average AUC of 0.85, ranging from 0.71 to 0.97, which was an improvement over previous studies that achieved an average LODO AUC of 0.81

question: How many new cohorts were sequenced specifically for this study?
reference: Six new cohorts were sequenced for this study, providing 1,625 new stool metagenomes. Four cohorts were part of the ONCOBIOME initiative, one was from the Nurses' Health Study II (NHSII), and one was from Turkey

question: What profiling tools were used to analyze the metagenomic samples?
reference: MetaPhlAn 4 was used for taxonomic profiling, HUMAnN 3.6 for functional profiling, and StrainPhlAn 4 for dominant strain profiling at single-nucleotide resolution

question: How many bacterial species-level genome bins (SGBs) were detected in total?
reference: A total of 3,866 bacterial SGBs, 15 eukaryotic SGBs, and 23 archaeal SGBs were detected across all samples

question: How does the oral-to-gut microbiome score differ between CRC patients and controls, and what does this indicate?
reference: The oral-to-gut microbiome score was significantly higher in CRC cases (Hedges' SMD = 0.47, P < 0.001) and increased further in later CRC stages (Hedges' SMD = 0.14, P = 0.003). Right-sided CRC showed higher presence of orally derived SGBs compared to left-sided CRC (Hedges' SMD = -0.23, P = 0.003), indicating that oral bacterial infiltration into the gut is a key differentiator of CRC stages and locations

question: What role does the gut microbiome play in ammonia production in CRC, and which enzymes are involved?
reference: The gut microbiome contributes to increased ammonia levels in CRC through L-histidine degradation pathways (SMD = 0.41 and 0.32, q < 0.1). The enzyme histidase (EC 4.3.1.3) cleaves L-histidine to produce urocanate and ammonia, and was enriched in CRC (SMD = 0.46, q < 0.1), late CRC (SMD = 0.18, P = 0.02), and metastatic CRC (SMD = 0.35, q < 0.1). Methylaspartate ammonia lyase (EC 4.3.1.2) was also highly associated with CRC (SMD = 0.45, q < 0.1)

question: Describe the relationship between the primary tumor presence and the stool microbiome signature in stage IV CRC patients
reference: In the AtezoTRIBE study of stage IV CRC patients, those with in situ primary tumors showed significantly different microbiome profiles compared to those with resected tumors (LODO AUC = 0.78). Thirteen of the 20 top CRC-associated SGBs (11 oral species) were significantly more abundant when the primary tumor was present (P < 0.05), confirming that the primary tumor microenvironment determines the overall stool microbiome signature in CRC

question: How did the study identify and characterize strain-level associations with CRC?
reference: The study used StrainPhlAn 4 for dominant strain profiling at single-nucleotide resolution and Anpan for gene carriage analysis. They identified 62 species with differential gene carriage (GLM FDR q < 0.05, absolute coefficient > 1) and 8 species with differential strain phylogenies in CRC (ELPD > 4). The analysis revealed that strain-level differentiation often occurred independently of species-level abundance changes, with 27 species showing phylogenetic associations specifically with metastatic CRC

question: What patterns of microbial succession were observed along the adenoma-carcinoma sequence?
reference: The microbiome changes occurred predominantly on a continuum rather than discrete stages. Parvimonas micra SGB6653 and Fusobacterium nucleatum SGB6007 showed increasing abundance starting from stage I. Seventeen SGBs were associated with late CRC versus only four with early CRC. Five oral-typical species (Slackia exigua, P. micra, Solobacterium, Dialister pneumosintes, and Streptococcus mutans) were significantly increased in late CRC. The microbiome of adenoma patients did not differ significantly from controls, suggesting the gut microbiome plays a more crucial role in the adenoma-carcinoma transition

question: How do sulfur-producing enzymes and oleate production pathways relate to CRC?
reference: Sulfur-producing enzymes were significantly associated with CRC, including homocysteine desulfhydrase (EC 4.4.1.2, SMD = 0.52, q < 0.001) and protein disulfide reductase (EC 1.8.1.8, SMD = 0.41, q < 0.001). Two pathways involved in oleate production in aerobes (PWY-6282, SMD = 0.4 and PWY-7664, SMD = 0.9, both q < 0.1) were also associated with CRC, supporting the hypothesis that oleate is linked to proliferation of cancerous cells

question: Compare the microbial signatures and their overlap between different CRC stages, cardiometabolic risk markers, and inflammatory diseases
reference: All CRC stages shared approximately 25% of species associated with cardiometabolic risk from the PREDICT 1 study. Stage 0 CRC had the highest proportion of oral bacteria (58%), while stage I showed the highest percentage of species common with poor cardiometabolic health (27%). All CRC stages shared SGBs with Crohn's disease and immune-mediated diseases, while stage IV shared 21% with poor cardiometabolic health markers. Importantly, only two SGBs (Hungatella hathewayi SGB4741 and Enterocloster aldensis SGB476) were common across cardiometabolic risk, inflammatory diseases, and CRC, indicating distinct yet partially overlapping microbial signatures

question: Explain the subspecies-level differentiation observed in Fusobacterium nucleatum and how different clades associate with CRC
reference: Five distinct F. nucleatum SGBs were identified with varying associations to CRC: SGB6007 (F. nucleatum animalis/Fna C2, SMD = 0.54), SGB6014 (F. nucleatum vincentii, SMD = 0.5), SGB6011 (F. nucleatum subsp. nucleatum/sensu stricto, SMD = 0.47), SGB6001 (F. nucleatum polymorphum, SMD = 0.43), and SGB6013 (Fna C1, SMD = 0.34), all q < 0.1. Phylogenetic analysis revealed subclades within these SGBs with differential prevalence in oral cavity versus gut environments. PhyloPhlAn 3 reconstruction showed F. nucleatum SGB6007 exhibited greater than 8 ELPD improvement in the phylogenetic model, indicating genomic adaptation to the intestinal environment beyond geographic variation

question: Describe the strain-specific gene carriage differences identified in Ruminococcus bicirculans and their functional implications for CRC progression
reference: Ruminococcus bicirculans SGB4262 showed significant phylogenetic associations with both late-stage CRC and metastatic CRC (top hit in both models with ELPD > 4). The species carried differentially abundant genes in CRC (Anpan taxon-wise q < 0.1, absolute estimate > 1), particularly genes involved in carbohydrate metabolism that showed higher carriage in later CRC stages. This is significant because carbohydrate metabolism is altered in CRC, and the findings suggest Firmicutes-specific metabolism could promote tumor differentiation. The strain-level analysis revealed that phylogenetic associations were independent of species-level abundance changes, indicating selection for specific R. bicirculans subclades during CRC progression

question: Compare the predictive performance and biological insights between using oral versus non-oral SGBs for CRC classification across different tumor characteristics
reference: When using only oral SGBs, the LODO approach achieved an average AUC of 0.83 compared to 0.85 with all SGBs, while non-oral SGBs alone achieved 0.79, indicating oral species contribute substantially but not exclusively to predictive power. For primary tumor location (right vs left), oral SGBs achieved an average AUC of 0.6 versus 0.66 with all SGBs. Significantly, 21 of 125 SGBs (16.8%) positively associated with CRC were oral-typical, compared to 34 of 488 (7.0%) non-significant SGBs (Fisher's test P < 0.01). At lower q thresholds (q < 0.05), 18 of 90 associated SGBs were oral. Dental plaque-associated species (11 of top oral SGBs) were more prevalent than tongue dorsum species (5 SGBs), suggesting biofilm-forming oral microbes play a major role in the intestinal CRC microbiome, particularly in right-sided tumors

question: How many countries were represented in the 18 cohorts analyzed in this study? Options: A) 8 countries B) 11 countries C) 15 countries D) 18 countries
reference: B. The study included 3,741 stool metagenomes from 18 cohorts across 11 countries, making it one of the most geographically diverse CRC microbiome studies
explanation: The study included 3,741 stool metagenomes from 18 cohorts across 11 countries, making it one of the most geographically diverse CRC microbiome studies

question: What percentage of CRC-associated oral SGBs were found at the q < 0.05 threshold? Options: A) 10 of 70 B) 15 of 80 C) 18 of 90 D) 21 of 100
reference: C. At the lower q threshold of q < 0.05, 18 out of 90 SGBs associated with CRC were oral-typical species, showing a strong enrichment of oral bacteria in CRC
explanation: At the lower q threshold of q < 0.05, 18 out of 90 SGBs associated with CRC were oral-typical species, showing a strong enrichment of oral bacteria in CRC

question: Which metabolite was specifically associated with stage IV CRC and confirmed previous findings? Options: A) Butyrate B) Acetate C) Methane D) Propionate
reference: C. The study confirmed previous findings linking methane metabolism (methanogenesis pathway, METHANOGENESIS-PWY, SMD = 0.4, P < 0.01) with stage IV CRC, with Methanobrevibacter smithii being one of the top associated species
explanation: The study confirmed previous findings linking methane metabolism (methanogenesis pathway, METHANOGENESIS-PWY, SMD = 0.4, P < 0.01) with stage IV CRC, with Methanobrevibacter smithii being one of the top associated species

question: What improvement in CRC prediction did the study achieve compared to previous meta-analyses using the LODO approach? Options: A) From 0.75 to 0.81 B) From 0.81 to 0.85 C) From 0.85 to 0.90 D) From 0.70 to 0.78
reference: B. The study improved the average LODO AUC from 0.81 (previous studies) to 0.85, representing a 4-point increase in predictive accuracy by leveraging increased sample sizes and improved methods
explanation: The study improved the average LODO AUC from 0.81 (previous studies) to 0.85, representing a 4-point increase in predictive accuracy by leveraging increased sample sizes and improved methods

question: How many species showed differential strain phylogenies associated with metastatic CRC? Options: A) 8 species B) 15 species C) 27 species D) 62 species
reference: C. Twenty-seven species exhibited phylogenetic associations with metastatic CRC (ELPD > 4), compared to only 8 species for broad CRC definition and 4 for early-late stage comparisons, highlighting the importance of strain-level analysis for understanding CRC progression
explanation: Twenty-seven species exhibited phylogenetic associations with metastatic CRC (ELPD > 4), compared to only 8 species for broad CRC definition and 4 for early-late stage comparisons, highlighting the importance of strain-level analysis for understanding CRC progression

question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between adenoma and CRC microbiomes compared to controls? Options: A) Both adenoma and CRC microbiomes differ significantly from controls B) Adenoma microbiomes differ from controls, but CRC does not C) Adenoma microbiomes do not differ from controls, but CRC microbiomes do D) Neither adenoma nor CRC microbiomes differ from controls
reference: C. The adenoma microbiome did not differ significantly from controls (PERMANOVA P ≥ 0.05), while CRC microbiomes were clearly distinct (R² = 0.014, P ≤ 0.01), suggesting the gut microbiome plays a more crucial role in the adenoma-carcinoma transition than in earlier phases
explanation: The adenoma microbiome did not differ significantly from controls (PERMANOVA P ≥ 0.05), while CRC microbiomes were clearly distinct (R² = 0.014, P ≤ 0.01), suggesting the gut microbiome plays a more crucial role in the adenoma-carcinoma transition than in earlier phases

question: What was the key finding regarding colibactin and fragilysin genes in CRC? Options: A) Both were highly enriched in CRC with strong effect sizes B) Neither showed significant enrichment in CRC at the strain level C) Only colibactin was significantly enriched D) Only fragilysin was significantly enriched
reference: B. Although colibactin-producing genes in E. coli and Klebsiella spp. and the fragilysin gene in B. fragilis showed increased carriage in CRC, neither reached significance (Anpan GLM q > 0.01, absolute coefficient < 1), suggesting their increased prevalence is due to species abundance rather than strain selection
explanation: Although colibactin-producing genes in E. coli and Klebsiella spp. and the fragilysin gene in B. fragilis showed increased carriage in CRC, neither reached significance (Anpan GLM q > 0.01, absolute coefficient < 1), suggesting their increased prevalence is due to species abundance rather than strain selection

question: Which oral-typical species was significantly associated with late-stage CRC but NOT with early-stage CRC? Options: A) Gemella morbillorum B) Fusobacterium nucleatum C) Parvimonas micra D) Dialister pneumosintes
reference: D. Among the five oral-typical species associated with late CRC, Dialister pneumosintes SGB5842 was specifically enriched in late stages, while P. micra was already increased in stage I and F. nucleatum was significantly increased starting in stage II
explanation: Among the five oral-typical species associated with late CRC, Dialister pneumosintes SGB5842 was specifically enriched in late stages, while P. micra was already increased in stage I and F. nucleatum was significantly increased starting in stage II

question: What was the correlation between machine learning feature importance and meta-analysis effect sizes for the control vs CRC comparison? Options: A) Spearman's correlation = 0.21 B) Spearman's correlation = 0.41 C) Spearman's correlation = 0.06 D) Spearman's correlation = 0.65
reference: B. The correlation between LODO-evaluated ML model average ranks and meta-analysis effect sizes was 0.41 (P < 0.001) for control vs CRC, demonstrating consistency between the two independent approaches. This was much higher than stage comparisons (0.06 for early vs late, 0.05 for non-metastatic vs metastatic)
explanation: The correlation between LODO-evaluated ML model average ranks and meta-analysis effect sizes was 0.41 (P < 0.001) for control vs CRC, demonstrating consistency between the two independent approaches. This was much higher than stage comparisons (0.06 for early vs late, 0.05 for non-metastatic vs metastatic)

question: Based on the carbon-nitrogen lyase gene carriage analysis, which species were identified as contributing to ammonia production in the CRC ecosystem? Options: A) Escherichia coli, Bacteroides fragilis, Fusobacterium nucleatum B) Klebsiella oxytoca, Odoribacter splanchnicus, Bacteroides intestinalis, Parasutterella excrementihominis, Clostridioides difficile C) Prevotella copri, Akkermansia muciniphila, Faecalibacterium prausnitzii D) Parvimonas micra, Gemella morbillorum, Peptostreptococcus stomatis
reference: B. Five species were identified encoding genes involved in ammonia production through carbon-nitrogen lyase activity: Klebsiella oxytoca, Odoribacter splanchnicus, Bacteroides intestinalis, Parasutterella excrementihominis, and Clostridioides difficile. P. excrementihominis specifically carried the argininosuccinate lyase gene, which produces ammonia as a known byproduct
explanation: Five species were identified encoding genes involved in ammonia production through carbon-nitrogen lyase activity: Klebsiella oxytoca, Odoribacter splanchnicus, Bacteroides intestinalis, Parasutterella excrementihominis, and Clostridioides difficile. P. excrementihominis specifically carried the argininosuccinate lyase gene, which produces ammonia as a known byproduct

question: What are the main oral pathogens enriched in patients with colorectal cancer according to meta-analyses?
reference: Meta-analyses of faecal metagenomes from patients with CRC have identified several core oral pathogens that are enriched, most notably Fusobacterium nucleatum, Parvimonas micra, Peptostreptococcus stomatis, P. anaerobius, Porphyromonas asaccharolytica, Solobacterium moorei and Prevotella intermedia

question: What percentage of gut microbial sequences are comprised of bacteria?
reference: Bacteria comprise 93% of gut microbial sequences in the gastrointestinal tract

question: Which probiotic strains have been recognized for inhibiting carcinogen-induced colorectal tumorigenesis in rodents since the 1980s?
reference: Probiotic strains such as L. acidophilus, L. rhamnosus GG and Bifidobacterium longum have been recognized as being able to inhibit carcinogen-induced colorectal tumorigenesis in rodents since the early 1980s

question: What are the two main types of secondary bile acids generated from primary bile acids by gut bacteria?
reference: Secondary bile acids such as deoxycholic and lithocholic acids are generated from primary bile acids by the sequential actions of bacterial bile acid hydrolases and bile acid 7α-dehydroxylases

question: What percentage of patients with CRC have MSI-high or MMR-deficient disease that responds to immune checkpoint inhibitors?
reference: Approximately 5% of patients with CRC have MMR-deficient or MSI-H disease that responds to immune checkpoint inhibitors. ICIs are largely ineffective in the remaining patients with microsatellite-stable CRC

question: How does Fusobacterium nucleatum promote colorectal tumorigenesis through its FadA adhesin?
reference: F. nucleatum expresses a cell-surface adhesin FadA which binds to E-cadherin on colonic epithelial cells and activates β-catenin signalling, leading to increased expression of cyclin D1, annexin A1 and Chk2 and tumorigenesis. Deletion of FadA impairs the ability of F. nucleatum to attach to and invade mammalian cells, thereby abrogating its tumour-promoting effects

question: Explain how Peptostreptococcus anaerobius promotes colorectal carcinogenesis at the molecular level
reference: P. anaerobius uses its putative cell wall binding repeat 2 (PCWBR2) protein to interact with integrin α2β1 on CRC cells, which in turn activates the PI3K–AKT signalling pathway via FAK kinase. Pharmacological blockade of integrin α2β1 using RDGS peptides has been shown to abolish the pro-tumorigenic effects of P. anaerobius in both CRC cells and in ApcMin/+ mice

question: How does colibactin produced by pks+ E. coli cause DNA damage that contributes to colorectal tumorigenesis?
reference: Colibactin is a genotoxin produced by E. coli harbouring the pks pathogenicity island. It forms DNA adducts and crosslinks, leading to double-strand breaks that result in AT-rich hexameric sequence motifs. The locations of colibactin-induced double-strand breaks correspond with mutational hotspots in the CRC genome, emphasizing its role in CRC tumorigenesis

question: What is the mechanism by which enterotoxigenic Bacteroides fragilis induces inflammation and promotes CRC?
reference: Enterotoxigenic B. fragilis-elicited inflammation begins with loss of gut barrier function, leading to rapid activation of the TH17 cell-dependent inflammatory cascade and activation of STAT3 and NF-κB signalling in IL-17R-expressing colonic epithelial cells. Additionally, enterotoxigenic B. fragilis inhibits exosomal miR-149-3p release from CRC cells to facilitate TH17 cell differentiation, forming a positive feedforward cycle. Blockade of IL-17 signalling abolishes this inflammation and inhibits CRC development

question: How do short-chain fatty acids like butyrate exert their anticancer effects in colorectal cancer?
reference: Butyrate exerts anticancer effects through multiple mechanisms: (1) By acting as a histone deacetylase inhibitor (HDAC), it promotes histone acetylation and expression of tumour suppressor proteins such as FAS, p21 and p27. (2) SCFAs bind to several tumour-suppressive G protein-coupled receptors including FFAR3, FFAR2 and hydroxycarboxylic acid receptor 2 expressed on non-malignant colonic epithelial cells. (3) Butyrate activates IFNγ+CD8+ T cells and NK cells, and (4) epigenetically activates ID2-mediated upregulation of IL-12 receptor expression in CD8+ T cells

question: What is the role of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) in gut dysbiosis-mediated CRC progression?
reference: Pathobionts foster an immunosuppressive tumour microenvironment by promoting intratumoural MDSC infiltration. Gut dysbiosis or the presence of pathogenic bacteria like F. nucleatum and P. anaerobius induces tumour-derived CXCL1, an MDSC chemoattractant. Microbial activation of the TLR–calcineurin–NFAT–IL-6 signalling cascade on polymorphonuclear MDSCs further promotes crosstalk with CRC cells to induce STAT3-dependent expression of co-inhibitory proteins B7H3/4, leading to suppression of cytotoxic T cells

question: Compare the roles of bacterial dysbiosis versus non-bacterial dysbiosis (fungi, viruses, Archaea) in colorectal cancer pathogenesis
reference: Bacterial dysbiosis is the most studied aspect, with enrichment of oral pathogens like F. nucleatum and depletion of beneficial bacteria forming pathobiont networks. Non-bacterial components show: (1) Viruses: enteric viromes altered with enrichment of Orthobunyavirus, Inovirus and Tunalikevirus genera, with trans-kingdom interactions between viral and bacterial communities. (2) Fungi: distinct mycobiome profiles with elevated Basidiomycota:Ascomycota ratio and enrichment of Aspergillus species, showing co-occurrence with pathogenic bacteria. (3) Archaea: greater abundance of halophilic Archaea but fewer methanogenic Archaea, with archaeal species correlating with oncogenic bacteria. Multi-kingdom interactions are evident, with bacteria-fungi showing strongest inter-kingdom interaction patterns

question: How does Fusobacterium nucleatum have contrasting effects on chemotherapy resistance versus immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy?
reference: F. nucleatum shows paradoxical effects: For chemotherapy, it promotes resistance to both oxaliplatin and 5-FU by eliciting protective autophagy through TLR4–MyD88 signalling and miR-18a*/4802-mediated repression of autophagy genes. It also drives NF-κB signalling and BIRC3 expression, inhibiting apoptosis. However, for immune checkpoint therapy, F. nucleatum paradoxically enhances anti-PD-L1 antibody efficacy. While colonization activates STING–NF-κB signalling and PD-L1 expression in CRC cells, it also promotes CD8+ T cell activation when PD-L1 is inhibited. Patients with tumours harbouring F. nucleatum or high faecal levels show improved responses and progression-free survival on anti-PD-1 antibodies

question: Describe the interplay between gut microbiota-derived gallic acid and mutant p53 in colorectal tumorigenesis
reference: The gut microbiota can switch mutant p53 from tumour-suppressive to oncogenic function. Depletion of gut microbiota using antibiotics supports the tumour-suppressive potential of mutant p53 in the distal colon in conditional Trp53R270H-knockin mice, attenuating colorectal tumorigenesis. Mechanistically, gut microbiota-derived gallic acid abolishes the tumour-suppressing function of mutant p53 and promotes CRC development in Trp53R270H mice via hyperactivation of WNT signalling. This demonstrates that genetic alterations and gut microbiota must work together in tumorigenesis

question: How does Streptococcus thermophilus-derived β-galactosidase suppress CRC development through metabolic reprogramming?
reference: S. thermophilus suppresses CRC development in azoxymethane/DSS-exposed or ApcMin/+ mice through its secreted β-galactosidase protein. This enzyme catalyses the formation of galactose both in vitro and in vivo, which impairs glucose utilization and activates oxidative phosphorylation, resulting in a 'reverse Warburg' effect. In this state, tumour cells become dependent on the same energy-generating processes as non-malignant cells (oxidative phosphorylation rather than glycolysis), resulting in tumour suppression

question: What percentage of patients with colorectal cancer have MSI-high disease that responds to immune checkpoint inhibitors? Options: A) ~2% B) ~5% C) ~10% D) ~15%
reference: B. Approximately 5% of patients with CRC have MMR-deficient or MSI-H disease that responds to immune checkpoint inhibitors. ICIs are largely ineffective in the remaining patients with microsatellite-stable disease
explanation: Approximately 5% of patients with CRC have MMR-deficient or MSI-H disease that responds to immune checkpoint inhibitors. ICIs are largely ineffective in the remaining patients with microsatellite-stable disease

question: Which bacterial adhesin from Fusobacterium nucleatum binds to E-cadherin and activates β-catenin signalling? Options: A) Fap2 B) FadA C) PCWBR2 D) Gingipain
reference: B. F. nucleatum expresses a cell-surface adhesin FadA which binds to E-cadherin on colonic epithelial cells and activates β-catenin signalling, leading to tumorigenesis. Fap2 is another F. nucleatum adhesin but it interacts with Gal–GalNAc
explanation: F. nucleatum expresses a cell-surface adhesin FadA which binds to E-cadherin on colonic epithelial cells and activates β-catenin signalling, leading to tumorigenesis. Fap2 is another F. nucleatum adhesin but it interacts with Gal–GalNAc

question: What is the primary mechanism by which butyrate exerts its anticancer effects? Options: A) Direct DNA damage B) Histone deacetylase inhibition C) Protease activation D) Cell membrane disruption
reference: B. Butyrate acts as a histone deacetylase inhibitor (HDAC), promoting histone acetylation and expression of tumour suppressor proteins such as FAS, p21 and p27. It also binds to tumour-suppressive G protein-coupled receptors
explanation: Butyrate acts as a histone deacetylase inhibitor (HDAC), promoting histone acetylation and expression of tumour suppressor proteins such as FAS, p21 and p27. It also binds to tumour-suppressive G protein-coupled receptors

question: Which genotoxin produced by pks+ E. coli causes DNA damage through formation of DNA adducts and crosslinks? Options: A) Cytolethal distending toxin (CDT) B) Colibactin C) B. fragilis toxin D) Indolimines
reference: B. Colibactin is a genotoxin produced by E. coli harbouring the pks pathogenicity island. It forms DNA adducts and crosslinks, leading to double-strand breaks with AT-rich hexameric sequence motifs that correspond with mutational hotspots in the CRC genome
explanation: Colibactin is a genotoxin produced by E. coli harbouring the pks pathogenicity island. It forms DNA adducts and crosslinks, leading to double-strand breaks with AT-rich hexameric sequence motifs that correspond with mutational hotspots in the CRC genome

question: What is the mechanism by which secondary bile acids promote colorectal tumorigenesis? Options: A) Direct tumour cell proliferation only B) Immune system activation C) Inflicting direct epithelial barrier damage, inducing oxidative DNA damage, and NF-κB activation D) Inhibition of tumour suppressor genes
reference: C. Secondary bile acids such as deoxycholic and lithocholic acids promote tumorigenesis by: (1) inflicting direct damage on the colonic epithelial barrier, (2) induction of oxidative DNA damage resulting in genomic instability, and (3) NF-κB activation. They can also promote gut dysbiosis
explanation: Secondary bile acids such as deoxycholic and lithocholic acids promote tumorigenesis by: (1) inflicting direct damage on the colonic epithelial barrier, (2) induction of oxidative DNA damage resulting in genomic instability, and (3) NF-κB activation. They can also promote gut dysbiosis

question: How does enterotoxigenic Bacteroides fragilis primarily promote colorectal tumorigenesis? Options: A) Direct DNA damage independent of inflammation B) Through TH17 cell-dependent inflammatory cascade and STAT3/NF-κB activation C) By producing secondary bile acids D) Through direct adhesin-receptor binding
reference: B. Enterotoxigenic B. fragilis promotes CRC primarily through inflammation. It causes loss of gut barrier function, leading to rapid activation of TH17 cell-dependent inflammatory cascade and activation of STAT3 and NF-κB signalling. It also inhibits exosomal miR-149-3p to facilitate TH17 differentiation
explanation: Enterotoxigenic B. fragilis promotes CRC primarily through inflammation. It causes loss of gut barrier function, leading to rapid activation of TH17 cell-dependent inflammatory cascade and activation of STAT3 and NF-κB signalling. It also inhibits exosomal miR-149-3p to facilitate TH17 differentiation

question: What distinguishes the mycobiome profile in patients with CRC compared to healthy individuals? Options: A) Decreased ratio of Basidiomycota to Ascomycota B) Elevated ratio of Basidiomycota to Ascomycota with enrichment of Aspergillus species C) Complete absence of Ascomycota D) No significant differences
reference: B. Patients with CRC show distinct mycobiome profiles characterized by an elevated ratio of Basidiomycota to Ascomycota. At the species level, several Aspergillus species are highly enriched, with Aspergillus rambellii being consistently enriched across cohorts and showing co-occurrence with pathogenic bacteria
explanation: Patients with CRC show distinct mycobiome profiles characterized by an elevated ratio of Basidiomycota to Ascomycota. At the species level, several Aspergillus species are highly enriched, with Aspergillus rambellii being consistently enriched across cohorts and showing co-occurrence with pathogenic bacteria

question: Which approach shows the LEAST promise for improving immune checkpoint inhibitor efficacy in colorectal cancer based on current evidence? Options: A) Faecal microbiota transplantation from responders B) Administration of specific probiotic cocktails like VE800 C) Dietary supplementation with soluble fiber/prebiotics D) Broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment
reference: D. While FMT from responders, specific probiotics like VE800, and dietary fiber supplementation all show promise in enhancing ICI efficacy, broad-spectrum antibiotics consistently show negative effects. Antibiotic use is correlated with inferior outcomes in patients receiving ICIs, and antibiotic-treated or germ-free mouse models show impaired responses to anti-CTLA4 and anti-PD-1 antibodies
explanation: While FMT from responders, specific probiotics like VE800, and dietary fiber supplementation all show promise in enhancing ICI efficacy, broad-spectrum antibiotics consistently show negative effects. Antibiotic use is correlated with inferior outcomes in patients receiving ICIs, and antibiotic-treated or germ-free mouse models show impaired responses to anti-CTLA4 and anti-PD-1 antibodies

question: What is the most significant limitation in using faecal microbial markers for colorectal cancer screening compared to traditional methods? Options: A) Lower specificity than FIT B) Higher cost than colonoscopy C) Reduced sensitivity for adenoma detection compared to advanced lesions D) Cannot be combined with other biomarkers
reference: C. While microbial markers show good performance for CRC detection (AUCs 0.8-0.9), their main limitation is reduced sensitivity for adenoma detection. For example, F. nucleatum shows AUC 0.89-0.94 for CRC but only ~34% sensitivity for adenomas. Even improved markers like Lachnoclostridium sp. 'm3' show ~50% sensitivity for adenomas. However, combining bacterial markers with FIT dramatically improves sensitivity (e.g., from 73.1% to 92.3% for CRC detection)
explanation: While microbial markers show good performance for CRC detection (AUCs 0.8-0.9), their main limitation is reduced sensitivity for adenoma detection. For example, F. nucleatum shows AUC 0.89-0.94 for CRC but only ~34% sensitivity for adenomas. Even improved markers like Lachnoclostridium sp. 'm3' show ~50% sensitivity for adenomas. However, combining bacterial markers with FIT dramatically improves sensitivity (e.g., from 73.1% to 92.3% for CRC detection)

question: Which mechanism BEST explains how the gut microbiota enhances oxaliplatin efficacy in colorectal cancer treatment? Options: A) Direct metabolic activation of oxaliplatin by bacterial enzymes B) Modulation of immunogenic cell death through TFH cell response and enhanced effector T cell activity C) Reducing drug metabolism and increasing bioavailability D) Preventing drug-induced toxicity only
reference: B. The gut microbiota potentiates oxaliplatin through multiple immune mechanisms: (1) Promoting intratumoural ROS production by myeloid cells, (2) Participating in oxaliplatin-induced immunogenic cell death via TFH-mediated immune response (abolished in germ-free and TLR2/4 knockout mice), and (3) Bacterial species like non-enterotoxigenic B. fragilis stimulating IL-1β and IL-12 from dendritic cells for TFH cell priming. SCFAs like butyrate also restore antitumour activity by activating CD8+ T cells through epigenetic regulation
explanation: The gut microbiota potentiates oxaliplatin through multiple immune mechanisms: (1) Promoting intratumoural ROS production by myeloid cells, (2) Participating in oxaliplatin-induced immunogenic cell death via TFH-mediated immune response (abolished in germ-free and TLR2/4 knockout mice), and (3) Bacterial species like non-enterotoxigenic B. fragilis stimulating IL-1β and IL-12 from dendritic cells for TFH cell priming. SCFAs like butyrate also restore antitumour activity by activating CD8+ T cells through epigenetic regulation

question: What percentage of stage I-III CRC patients relapse within 5 years after tumor removal?
reference: 24% of patients with stage I-III CRC relapse within 5 years after tumor removal, with more than half of these cases occurring within 2 years

question: How many CRC patients were included in the study and what was the median follow-up period for progression?
reference: 333 patients with primary CRC were included in the study. The median follow-up period was 27.6 months for progression (with 29.5 months for non-progressed patients) and 43.6 months for overall survival

question: What are the two main enterotypes observed in CRC patients and which bacterial genera represent them?
reference: The gut microbiota of CRC patients was clustered into two enterotypes: enterotype 1 dominated by Bacteroides and enterotype 2 dominated by Prevotella, with a reciprocal distribution of these representative genera

question: What are the four novel prognostic bacteria identified in addition to Fusobacterium nucleatum?
reference: The four novel prognostic bacteria identified are: Bacteroides sp. (assigned to Alistipes including A. dispar and A. senegalensis), Pyramidobacter piscolens, and Dialister invisus. These bacteria indicated a high risk of CRC progression

question: In the M5-low group, how many patients progressed out of the total?
reference: In the M5-low group, only 2 patients progressed out of 74 total patients, indicating a very low rate of progression for patients with high Prevotella abundance and no pathobionts

question: How does the prevalence of Prevotella differ between Western and non-Western populations according to the meta-analysis?
reference: A meta-analysis of over 6,500 metagenomes found that P. copri prevalence is 95.4% among individuals living a non-Western lifestyle compared to only 29.6% among individuals with a Western lifestyle. In the Korean cohort studied, Prevotella was detected in 90.7% of CRC patients (302/333) with a median abundance of 15.8%

question: Explain how the microbial hazard score M5 was constructed and what scores were assigned to different risk categories
reference: The M5 score was constructed using five bacteria: Prevotella genus and four pathobionts (Bacteroides sp., P. piscolens, D. invisus, and F. nucleatum). A score of 1 was assigned to samples with low Prevotella abundance (<16.1%), and a score of 1 was assigned for each pathobiont present. The scores were categorized into: M5-low (score 0), M5-moderate (scores 1-2), and M5-high (scores 3-5) for clear stratification of patient risk

question: What screening method was used to identify prognostic bacterial species and what were the selection criteria?
reference: Among 438 bacterial species, 79 species with prevalence ≥10% and relative abundance ≥0.01% were selected for screening. Both univariate log-rank survival test and multivariate Cox proportional hazard analysis were performed using the entire dataset and 1000 random subsamples. Species with high effect size (HR >1.5) and significance (FDR <0.1) were selected as prognostic biomarkers, with the number of consistent discriminations in both discovery and validation sets used to measure robustness

question: What were the adjusted hazard ratios for the four novel prognostic pathobionts after controlling for confounding factors?
reference: After adjustment for TNM stages, lymphatic invasion, neoadjuvant treatment, postoperative chemotherapy, and CEA level, the adjusted hazard ratios were: P. piscolens 2.52, D. invisus 2.30, F. nucleatum 2.04, and Bacteroides sp. 1.86. All species significantly predicted disease progression

question: Describe the association between gut microbiota and clinical parameters using PERMANOVA
reference: PERMANOVA analysis revealed that gut microbiota based on Bray-Curtis dissimilarity was significantly associated with: clinicopathological stage (P=0.012), CRC progression (P=0.011), and decease (P=0.007). Additionally, TNM staging systems showed associations: T-stage (P=0.012), N-stage (P=0.063), and M-stage (P=0.01). However, neoadjuvant treatment, postoperative chemotherapy, comorbidity, and most medications were not associated with the gut microbiome

question: How did the bacterial families Akkermansiaceae, Fusobacteriaceae, and Prevotellaceae differ between patients with and without progression?
reference: Akkermansiaceae and Fusobacteriaceae tended to increase in patients with progression (P=0.0039 and P=0.1575 respectively), while Prevotellaceae decreased (P=0.0228). This suggests that increased pathobiont families and decreased beneficial Prevotellaceae are associated with poorer CRC outcomes

question: Compare the performance of the M5 microbial hazard score with traditional clinical biomarkers in predicting CRC progression
reference: M5 outperformed all traditional biomarkers when added to the baseline model based on cancer stage. The concordance index increased from 0.69 (baseline) to 0.78 (with M5). The adjusted hazard ratios were: M5-high 19.54, M5-moderate 6.53, and M5-numerical 2.07 (95% CI 1.61-2.64, P=7.8e-9). This performance surpassed CEA, fibrinogen, age, lymphatic invasion, BMI, and NLR. The increase in C-index by M5 (+0.0876) was comparable to the combined consideration of CEA, lymphatic invasion, and age (+0.0885)

question: What microbial pathways were identified through PICRUSt2 analysis as differentially abundant between M5-low and M5-high groups, and what is their functional significance?
reference: PICRUSt2 identified 15 differentially abundant pathways (FDR <0.001, ΔTRFA >5). Nine beneficial pathways enriched in M5-low included: Calvin-Benson-Bassham cycle, thiamine diphosphate salvage II (P=0.0087), thiamine diphosphate biosynthesis I, flavin biosynthesis I, preQ0 biosynthesis, and fatty acid biosynthesis pathways. Six detrimental pathways depleted in M5-low included: glycogen degradation I, glycolysis I and II, pyrimidine deoxyribonucleoside salvage, and L-histidine degradation I (P=0.032). The thiamine salvage pathway showed taxonomic contribution from various bacterial families forming a beneficial consortium, while detrimental pathways were mainly from Bacteroidaceae. Both pathways correlated with CD8+ T cell numbers in tumor epithelium

question: Explain the clinical characteristics that differed between M5-low and M5-high groups and discuss the implications
reference: M5-high patients compared to M5-low showed: older age (68 vs 61 years, P=0.0656), higher CEA levels (57.7% vs 12.2% CEA-high, P=0.0001248), more advanced cancer stages (only 5.7% stage 0/1 vs 31.1% in M5-low, P=0.002322), increased lymphatic invasion (34.0% vs 24.3%), lower MSI (5.7% vs 21.2%, P=0.00797), and higher type 2 diabetes prevalence (28.3% vs 13.5%, P=0.119). The M5-high group also had lower alcohol consumption (15.1% vs 47.3%, P=0.001077) and more systemic illness (ASA class 3: 15.1% vs 4.1%). These findings suggest convergent characteristics between gut microbiota of CRC and metabolic diseases like diabetes

question: What is the relationship between the oral microbiota and the identified prognostic biomarkers, and why might this be clinically significant?
